context: Higher dimethylsulfide, 2-buthane thiol and H2S concentrations were found in the air in June than in September. SO2 values were also lower in September air samples. Measured data indicated that the odor generating capacity of the creeks have been reduced after domestic and industrial wastewater discharges were cut off. Disregarding the low molecular weight thiols that could not be found, 2-propane thiol and 2-butane thiol as well as the dimethylsulfide and H2S were found to be the major components in emissions and ambient air. All of these emission concentrations have notably reduced between June and September 2001 campaigns. Occasional appearance of diphenylsulfide in June samples needs more careful investigations for sources. Thiophenes have possibly arisen in creek waters due to fuel contamination upstream and exhaust gases of dense traffic near the creek sites.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, Methylsulfanylmethane (dimethylsulfide) is identified as a significant component among the emissions and ambient air samples analyzed, alongside other sulfhydryl compounds such as 2-propane thiol and 2-butane thiol. Both Methylsulfanylmethane and sulfhydryl compounds are discussed in relation to their presence in air samples, indicating a shared category of volatile sulfur compounds. However, the specific interactions or functional relationships between them are not elaborated upon, limiting the depth of their connection.
llm_generation.reason: The score of 2 reflects an indirect connection, as both Methylsulfanylmethane and sulfhydryl compounds are mentioned in the context of air emissions, but their relationship lacks detailed discussion or evidence of direct interaction.
